bestBHT.bht: The preaching of Christ, the mystery of the Gospel hidden from eternity in the counsels of God, is proclaimed to establish believers. The mystery, once unknown but now revealed, has been kept in silence during eternal ages. Through the preaching of Jesus Christ, believers are strengthened and confirmed according to the gospel. The doxology at the end of this epistle emphasizes the grandeur of the divine plan and the praise due to God for His revealed mystery.

Henry Alford: The preaching of Christ, i.e. making known of Christ.
The mystery of the Gospel is often said to have been thus hidden from eternity in the counsels of God.
The mystery of the Gospel is often said to have been thus hidden From eternity in the counsels of God.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: To Him that is able to stablish you, according to my gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ.
In conformity with the truths of that Gospel which I preach, and not I only, but all to whom has been committed 'the preaching of Jesus Christ.'
Which hath been kept in silence during eternal ages.
Albert Barnes: God only can keep Christians in the path of salvation; and it was well to bring that truth prominently into view at the close of the Epistle.

The doctrines which he had advanced were just those which were suited to strengthen and confirm them, - the doctrine of justification, of election, of perseverance, and of the protection and favor of God to both Jews and Gentiles.
The word here seems to refer to the principal doctrines of the gospel; its main truths, which had been concealed, especially from the entire Gentile world, but which were now made known.
Marvin Vincent: The doxology stands at the close of this chapter in most of the very oldest MSS., and in the Peshito or Syriac and Vulgate versions.
The particular mystery of the conversion of the Gentiles, which is emphasized in Ephesians 3:3-9; Colossians 1:26, is included, but the reference is not to be limited to this.
Kept secret [σεσιγημενου]. Rev., more accurately, kept in silence. In Ephesians 3:9; Colossians 1:26, ajpokekrummenon hidden away, is used.
Philip Schaff: Who is able to stablish you. Comp. marginal references. This description of God is appropriate in this Epistle.

And the preaching of Jesus Christ. This is closely joined with the preceding phrase, and is probably an explanation of it; either the preaching concerning Christ, which is the substance of his gospel, or the preaching which Christ causes to be promulgated through him.

Hath been kept in silence during eternal ages. The thought is a common one in the Apostle’s writings. ‘Eternal ages’ include all the ages of human history, but also plainly suggest that eternal past when God formed his counsels of redemption (Ephesians 1:4).
Archibald T. Robertson: Verses Romans 16:25-27 conclude the noble Epistle with the finest of Paul's doxologies.
To stablish (στηριξα). First aorist active infinitive of στηριζω, to make stable.
Of the mystery (μυστηριου). Once unknown, but now revealed.
John Gill: The Gospel is... better calculated for, and with a divine blessing always issues in the establishment of the saints.
The Gospel... treats of his person, offices, righteousness, blood, sacrifice, and salvation...
The Gospel... often in Scripture called a 'mystery', because the reason of many of its important doctrines does not clearly appear to the carnal reason of men...
John Wesley: Now to him who is able... To establish you — Both Jews and gentiles."
According to my gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ — That is, according to the tenor of the gospel of Jesus Christ, which I preach."
According to the revelation of the mystery — Of the calling of the gentiles, which, as plainly as it was foretold in the Prophets, was still hid from many even of the believing Jews.

bhtAttempts.bht: The preaching of Christ, the mystery of the Gospel hidden from eternity in the counsels of God, is proclaimed and made known to establish believers. This mystery, once unknown, but now revealed, has been kept in silence during eternal ages. It is through the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the tenor of the gospel, that believers, both Jews and Gentiles, are strengthened and confirmed. God's ability to establish is showcased in this letter, where the main truths of the gospel, concealed from the Gentile world, are made known. The doxology at the end of this epistle emphasizes the grandeur of the divine plan and the praise due to God for His revealed mystery.

The mystery of the Gospel, hidden from eternity in the counsels of God, is now proclaimed and made known through the preaching of Jesus Christ to establish believers. This mystery, concealed during eternal ages, is revealed in the gospel, preached by Paul, and is not limited to the conversion of the Gentiles alone. Believers, both Jews and Gentiles, are strengthened and confirmed through the gospel, which God has the ability to establish, as highlighted in this doxology that concludes the noble Epistle of Romans.

The preaching of Christ, the mystery of the Gospel hidden from eternity in the counsels of God, is proclaimed to establish believers. The mystery, once unknown but now revealed, has been kept in silence during eternal ages. Through the preaching of Jesus Christ, believers are strengthened and confirmed according to the gospel. The doxology at the end of this epistle emphasizes the grandeur of the divine plan and the praise due to God for His revealed mystery.

Proclaiming the mystery of the Gospel, hidden from eternity in the counsels of God, is essential for establishing believers. This long-concealed mystery, which has been kept in silence for eternal ages, is now brought to light through the preaching of Jesus Christ. By embracing the truths of the gospel, believers, both Jews and Gentiles, find stability and confirmation in their faith. The doxology that concludes this epistle magnifies the greatness of God's revealed mystery and calls for adoration and praise.

The mystery of the Gospel, hidden in the counsels of God, is proclaimed to establish believers. This long-concealed mystery, kept in silence for eternal ages, is now revealed through the preaching of Jesus Christ. Embracing the truths of the gospel provides believers, both Jews and Gentiles, with stability and confirmation in their faith. The doxology at the end of this epistle glorifies the greatness of God's revealed mystery, calling for praise and adoration.
